SystemOutput:
CC:

Fatigue, lightheadedness, and shortness of breath.

HPI:

Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. He has been feeling out of sorts, fatigued, and lightheaded for about five weeks. He has also experienced shortness of breath during home projects. He denies fever, chills, significant cough, or chest pain. He has been taking his medications and monitoring his blood pressure at home. He reports a recent change in diet due to home renovations.

EXAM:

Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals jugular venous distention to about 8 centimeters, a 3/6 systolic ejection murmur, fine crackles at the lung bases bilaterally, and 1+ pitting edema in the lower extremities.

RESULTS:

Chest x-ray shows some fluid in the lungs. Echocardiogram from four months ago shows a reduced ejection fraction of 45% and mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT:

1. Congestive heart failure with fluid retention.
2. Hypertension, well-managed.

PLAN:

1. For congestive heart failure, increase Lasix to 80 mg once a day. Instruct the patient to weigh himself daily and call if weight gain or shortness of breath occurs. Order a follow-up echocardiogram.
2. For hypertension, continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily. Instruct the patient to continue monitoring blood pressure at home and report any elevations through the patient portal.

Follow up with the patient after test results are received.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents with right knee pain after a fall from a ladder while changing a light bulb. She reports twisting her knee while trying to catch her fall. The incident occurred yesterday. The pain is located on the inside of her knee. She has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but it has not provided significant relief.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Atrial fibrillation, currently taking digoxin.

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY

Rhinoplasty.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Musculoskeletal: Tenderness over the medial portion of the right knee, over the medial meniscus area. Pain with valgus stress. Normal sensation.
• Neurological: Normal sensation in lower extremities.

RESULTS

X-ray of the left knee: No fractures or dislocations. A small amount of fluid is present. Proper alignment.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female presenting with right knee pain after a fall from a ladder.

Acute medial meniscus strain.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has tenderness over the medial meniscus area and pain with valgus stress. X-ray shows no fractures or dislocations.
• Medical Treatment: Prescribe Motrin 800 mg every 6 hours with food for two weeks. Provide a knee brace and crutches for temporary use.
• Patient Education and Counseling: Advise the patient to return in one week for a follow-up. If the pain is not improved, an MRI will be considered.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Back pain.

HPI:

Mr. Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with lower back pain. He reports lifting heavy boxes too quickly on Saturday, which resulted in a popping sound and pain in his lower back. He has been using Tylenol, ibuprofen, and icy heat for pain relief with minimal improvement. He experienced tingling in his right toes until Sunday afternoon. He has difficulty finding a comfortable position for sleeping.

PMH:

Diabetes type 2, hypertension, osteoarthritis.

EXAM:

Physical examination reveals a 2/6 systolic heart murmur, pain to palpation of the lumbar spine, and pain with flexion and extension of the back. Negative straight leg raise. Blood pressure is slightly elevated.

RESULTS:

Diabetes labs: Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.
Back x-ray: Normal, with good bony alignment and no fractures.

IMPRESSION:

1. Lumbar strain.
2. Diabetes type 2, poorly controlled.
3. Hypertension, poorly controlled.
4. Osteoarthritis, stable.

PLAN:

1. Lumbar strain: Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg once a day, continue icing, avoid strenuous activity, and refer to physical therapy.
2. Diabetes type 2: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice a day, repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.
3. Hypertension: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.
4. Osteoarthritis: Continue monitoring and conservative management.

The patient has no further questions. The nurse will assist with check-out.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam and follow-up of chronic problems.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, hypertension, and prior lobectomy. He presents for his annual exam. The patient reports managing his depression well with Prozac and has not had any incidents recently. He has been struggling more with his hypertension, taking Norvasc regularly during the business week but occasionally forgetting on weekends. Ralph had a lobectomy a couple of years ago and has experienced shortness of breath with exertion, particularly during humid weather. He runs 4-5 miles daily as his workout.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat: Nasal congestion due to pollen.
• Cardiovascular: Shortness of breath with exertion, occasional chest pounding during runs.
• Respiratory: No cough or wheezing.
• Psychiatric: Endorses depression, managed with Prozac.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Musculoskeletal: No lower extremity edema.
• Head, Eyes, Ears, Nose, and Throat: Pain to palpation of sinuses.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: 120/80 mmHg.

RESULTS

Electrocardiogram: Normal.
Chest X-ray: Normal, no concerns related to prior lobectomy.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Depression.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is managing well with Prozac.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Prozac 20 mg daily. Refill ordered.
   
2. Hypertension.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient has improved blood pressure control but admits to occasional noncompliance on weekends.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Norvasc as prescribed. Encourage compliance on weekends.

3. Status post lobectomy.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is exercising regularly and has good breathing function.
   • Medical Treatment: No further follow-up with the surgeon is needed.

4. Systolic ejection murmur.
   • Additional Testing: Order an echocardiogram.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right finger pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Sharon Brooks is a 48-year-old female presenting with right finger pain. The patient reports that she was skiing four days ago and experienced an injury to her right finger when it was bent backwards while going over a mogul. She has tried ice and ibuprofen for pain management, but the pain persists. The pain is worse with movement.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

The patient has a history of constipation and takes Miralax for management. She had an appendectomy at age 18.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Musculoskeletal: Tenderness over the distal phalanx of the right index finger. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint. Pain with flexion.

RESULTS
Imaging

X-ray: No fractures identified. Everything lines up well.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Sharon Brooks is a 48-year-old female presenting with right finger pain after a skiing injury. Based on the physical examination and x-ray results, the diagnosis is a right hand index finger contusion on the tip of the finger.

• Medical Treatment: Prescribe Motrin 600 mg every six hours for one week.
• Additional Treatment: Provide an aluminum foam splint for the affected finger.
• Patient Education and Counseling: Instruct the patient to call and return for a follow-up if the pain does not improve within a week.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Iron deficiency anemia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female with a long-standing history of iron deficiency anemia. She was recently unable to donate blood due to her anemia. The patient reports fatigue, feverishness with chills, shortness of breath, wheezing, and headaches. She also experiences cold intolerance and worsening anxiety and depression. She has been anemic since the age of 13 and had a hysterectomy in 1996.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• General: Fatigue, feverishness, chills, and cold intolerance.
• Respiratory: Shortness of breath and wheezing.
• Neurological: Headaches.
• Psychiatric: Worsening anxiety and depression.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

• Iron deficiency anemia
• Hysterectomy in 1996

MEDICATIONS

• Ferrous sulfate 25 mg tablets, twice daily
• Over-the-counter vitamin B12

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops, or rubs. No extra heart sounds.
• Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, and non-distended. No organomegaly or masses.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female with a long-standing history of iron deficiency anemia.

Iron deficiency anemia.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has been anemic since the age of 13 and had a hysterectomy in 1996. She is currently taking ferrous sulfate and vitamin B12 supplements.
• Additional Testing: Schedule an upper endoscopy and colonoscopy to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed. If inconclusive, consider capsule endoscopy.
• Specialist Referrals: Refer the patient to a hematologist for further evaluation and management.
• Patient Education and Counseling: Instruct the patient to continue taking ferrous sulfate with orange juice (for vitamin C) for the next 12 weeks, then recheck CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate levels.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual visit.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient is a 27-year-old female who presents for her annual visit. The patient reports that she has been doing better since her last visit. She reports that she has been struggling with her depression off and on for the past year. The patient notes that it might be due been trapped inside and remotely over the past year. She reports that she is taking Prozac 20 mg, but she believes that it has been weighing on her lately. She notes that an increase in her Prozac dose might be beneficial for her at this time.

The patient reports that she has had chronic back pain that she has been managing. She reports that she experiences stiffness and pain when she sits or stands for long periods of time at her desk at work. She reports that it helps when she gets up and moves. She reports that she has a little bit of numbness down her legs, but no tingling or pain down her legs. She reports that the symptoms improve when she stands up or changes positions. She denies any weakness in her legs.

She reports that she has had a coronary artery bypass grafting. She reports that she had a congenital artery when she was a baby and they had to do a CABG on her fairly young age. She reports that her heart has been doing well and her arteries have been looking good.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Musculoskeletal: Endorses back pain.
• Neurological: Endorses numbness in legs.
• Psychiatric: Endorses depression.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: in no apparent distress.
• Neck: Supple without thyromegaly.
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
• Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation of the lumbar spine. Decreased flexion of back. Lower extremity strength is good.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram appears unchanged in comparison to last year.

X-rays of the lumbar spine stable in comparison to last year.

ASSESSMENT

The patient is a 27-year-old female who presents today for an annual followup of chronic conditions.

Chronic back pain.
• Medical Reasoning: She is experiencing worsened pain with sitting for extended periods of time.
• Medical Treatment: Physical therapy referral ordered. Patient would like to defer pain medication at this time.

Depression
• Medical Reasoning: The patient was previously doing well on Prozac 20 mg once daily but feels as though she needs a higher dose at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Increase Prozac to 40 mg once daily. Prescription submitted.

History of coronary artery bypass graft.
• Medical Reasoning: She is doing well at this time. We will continue to monitor this.
• Medical Treatment: Echocardiogram ordered. Continue aspirin 81 mg daily.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Ms. Hill, a 53-year-old female, presents with a history of chest pain and difficulty swallowing that occurred three months ago.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Hill reports experiencing chest pain in early October 2020, which lasted for four days. The pain was located in the center of her chest, behind her breastbone, and was sharp in nature. She went to the emergency room, where they performed an EKG and blood tests, but all results were normal. The ER suspected a GI issue and referred her to our clinic. The patient also experienced difficulty swallowing during the episode, which has since resolved. She denies any current chest pain or swallowing issues.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: Denies current chest pain.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies abdominal pain, normal bowel movements. Reports mild tenderness in the upper abdomen during the exam.
• Neurological: Denies dizziness or lightheadedness.
• Psychiatric: Reports a stressful job transition around the time of the chest pain episode.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

• Uterine fibroids
• Anemia
• Cholecystectomy (gallbladder removal)

FAMILY HISTORY

No known family history of GI problems.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Abdomen: Mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants. No other abnormalities noted.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Ms. Hill is a 53-year-old female presenting with a history of chest pain and difficulty swallowing that occurred three months ago. Possible etiologies include GERD, dyspepsia, esophagitis, musculoskeletal issues, and anxiety. The patient's symptoms may have been related to an anxiety attack due to her job transition, with a possible contribution from musculoskeletal issues.

The patient was offered the option of an EGD or to continue monitoring her symptoms. She elected to self-monitor her symptoms and will call with any reoccurrence or change. The patient will follow up as needed for any other GI complaints.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with Smith-Magenis Syndrome. She is a twin and was born at 34 weeks and 3 days gestation. She has a history of feeding difficulties, reflux, and developmental delays. She is currently in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, physical therapy, and will soon start speech therapy. She has seen multiple specialists, including a geneticist, orthopedic, ophthalmologist, and audiologist. The geneticist mentioned possible kidney issues associated with her syndrome.

The patient has a good urine output, with 8-10 wet diapers per day. She drinks a combination of pea protein milk, water, and occasionally water with a small amount of juice.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined.
• Eyes: Small appearing.
• Musculoskeletal: Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities and arms.
• Genitourinary: Normal external female genitalia.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined.
• Eyes: Small appearing.
• Musculoskeletal: Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities and arms.
• Genitourinary: Normal external female genitalia.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with Smith-Magenis Syndrome. Several organ systems can be affected by this chromosomal deletion syndrome. Congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract have been reported in the literature.

We will obtain a screening of the kidneys by ultrasound today. If there are abnormalities on the kidney ultrasound, we will determine next steps and future follow-up. The family lives in Dallas, Georgia, so her follow-up should be at the town center location.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist pain and swelling after a fall.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Diana is a patient who presents with right wrist pain and swelling after slipping on the stairs while doing laundry. The injury occurred yesterday morning. She has not had any previous injuries to this arm. The pain is rated as 9/10 in severity. She has tried icing the wrist, using an ace wrap, and taking ibuprofen with minimal relief. She experiences mild tingling in her fingers but denies any numbness.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Head and Neck: No adenopathy, thyromegaly, or carotid bruit.
• Cardiovascular: No murmur, rub, or gallop.
• Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• Musculoskeletal: Right wrist with obvious swelling, ecchymosis, and tenderness on palpation. Pain on flexion, extension, radial deviation, and ulnar deviation. Able to make a fist but not tightly. Bony crepitus present.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: Slightly elevated at 140/70 mmHg.
• Heart Rate: Slightly elevated at 80 beats per minute.
• Temperature: Normal at 97.2°F.
• Respiratory Rate: Normal at 20 breaths per minute.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Diana presents with right wrist pain and swelling after a fall. X-ray results indicate a Colles' fracture.

1. Colles' fracture.
   • Medical Reasoning: Positive for fracture based on x-ray results and physical exam findings.
   • Additional Testing: None needed at this time.
   • Medical Treatment: Schedule surgery for fracture repair. In the meantime, provide a brace for the wrist. Prescribe 50 mg of Ultram every 6 hours for pain management.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Inform the patient about the need for surgery and the expected recovery timeline. Discuss the possibility of postponing vacation depending on the progress of physical therapy.

2. Physical therapy.
   • Medical Reasoning: To aid in the recovery and strengthening of the wrist post-surgery.
   • Medical Treatment: Begin physical therapy a few weeks after surgery, with an assessment to determine the frequency of sessions.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right knee pain.

HPI:

Philip is a patient with a past medical history of hypertension who presents today with right knee pain after slipping and falling while working on his property a week ago. He reports feeling a pop during the fall and has experienced swelling and pain, rating it 4/5 when moving. He has been taking ibuprofen for the swelling. He has been taking his hypertension medication (20 mg Lisinopril) regularly but admits to struggling with dietary changes to reduce sodium intake.

EXAM:

Lungs: Clear bilaterally, no wheezes or crackles.
Heart: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
Right knee: Pain to palpation of the medial aspect, pain with flexion and extension, edema around the knee, and effusion present.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right knee obtained prior to the visit show no fractures or bony abnormalities.

IMPRESSION:

1. Right knee MCL strain.
2. Hypertension.

PLAN:

1. For the right knee MCL strain, prescribe ibuprofen 800 mg twice a day for pain and swelling, provide a knee brace for support, and recommend icing the knee for 20 minutes at a time, 3-4 times a day. Advise the patient to elevate and stay off the leg.
2. Continue 20 mg Lisinopril for hypertension and provide a referral to nutrition for dietary guidance to help manage sodium intake and potentially reduce the need for medication in the future.

All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Wayne is a middle-aged male who presents to the clinic today with left shoulder pain for approximately three weeks. He denies any specific injury but mentions being active and recently working on renovating his basement. The patient reports difficulty reaching for objects and lifting, as well as increased pain when lying on the affected shoulder. He has been taking extra strength Tylenol every six to eight hours for pain relief, which helps to some extent but does not completely alleviate the pain.

PAST HISTORY

No significant past medical history.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Active lifestyle, currently renovating basement.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Extra strength Tylenol as needed for pain.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Left shoulder exam reveals limited active and passive range of motion, tenderness of the greater tuberosity of the humerus, no tenderness at the sternoclavicular or acromioclavicular joints, and good hand grips. Neurovascular exam of the left arm shows capillary refill less than three seconds and intact sensation to light touch.

RESULTS
Imaging

Left shoulder x-ray: No fractures.

ASSESSMENT

Left shoulder pain, likely due to rotator cuff tendinopathy.

PLAN

1. Order MRI for left shoulder to further evaluate the cause of pain.
2. Refer the patient to physical therapy for 6-8 weeks.
3. Continue Tylenol for pain management.
4. Consider steroid injection for the shoulder if symptoms do not improve after physical therapy.
5. Schedule a follow-up visit after completion of physical therapy.

The patient was provided with educational materials on physical therapy and advised to schedule a follow-up visit after completing the therapy.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a patient who presents with occasional left knee pain. She reports that the pain occurs less than once a day while walking, and her knee suddenly feels like it is going to give out. The pain is internal and involves the whole kneecap. She denies any history of injury to the knee and has not taken any medication for the pain as it does not last long. The patient is concerned about an upcoming trip where she will be doing a lot of walking and participating in line dancing, and she does not want to risk her knee giving out during these activities.

The patient also reports that her blood pressure has been stable, and she has been taking her blood pressure medications regularly. She has also been monitoring her blood sugar levels, which have been slightly elevated in the mornings.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or shortness of breath.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses left knee pain.
• Endocrine: Reports slightly elevated morning blood sugar levels.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Vital Signs: Temperature 98.2, Pulse 72, Respirations 16, Blood Pressure 122/70.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base.
• Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• Musculoskeletal: Left knee exam reveals no ecchymosis, edema, effusion, or pain to palpation. Range of motion is not decreased. Negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS

Left knee x-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Left knee pain: Suspect arthritis. Plan to prescribe Meloxicam 15 mg daily and consider physical therapy to strengthen the muscles around the knee and prevent further problems.

2. Hypertension: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily. Order an echocardiogram to evaluate the heart murmur.

3. Diabetes Mellitus: Order a Hemoglobin A1c to assess the need for adjustments to Metformin. Order a lipid panel for further evaluation.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Hospital follow-up for heart failure.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of hypertension and recent hospitalization for heart failure.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking Bumex 2 mg once daily, Cozaar 100 mg daily, and Norvasc 5 mg once daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies sleep disturbance.
Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain.
Respiratory: Reports improvement in shortness of breath.
Genitourinary: Reports urinary incontinence in the setting of diuretic medication.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: 128/72 mmHg
Temperature: 98.7 degrees F
Heart Rate: 72 bpm
Respirations: 18
Oxygen Saturation: 96%

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck
- General Examination: No jugular venous distention.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Stable 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: Trace lower extremity edema.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram reveals a preserved ejection fraction of 55%, abnormal diastolic filling, and mild-to-moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive heart failure.
- Medical Reasoning: This appears to have been caused by dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged the patient to continue making dietary modifications, including limiting her sodium intake. She could try keeping a food diary, as previously discussed, to log her diet and associated blood pressure readings. I also advised her to monitor her weight daily and contact me if she gains 3 pounds in 2 days.
- Medical Treatment: Continue with Bumex 2 mg once daily. Referral placed for consult with a nutritionist for education and recommendations regarding her diet.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: This has been poorly controlled due to inconsistent compliance with medication and dietary indiscretion.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed dietary modifications as noted above.
- Medical Treatment: She can continue on Cozaar 100 mg daily and Norvasc 5 mg once daily. Renal artery ultrasound ordered to rule out any issues such as renal artery stenosis.

3. Kidney disease.
- Medical Treatment: Labs will be ordered to assess her response to new medications.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 3 months.

CC:

Low Immunoglobulin A level

HPI:

Kyle is a patient who was referred for evaluation of a low Immunoglobulin A level. The patient reports frequent colds during the winter season and states that they tend to linger for a long time. No significant abdominal infections or family history of immune deficiencies. Recently diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes and started on Metformin. No history of blood transfusions or blood products.

EXAM:

Vitals: Stable, no fever
Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs
Lungs: Clear, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi
Neck: No lymphadenopathy
Abdomen: Soft, non-tender

LABS:

Recent lab work consistent with IgA deficiency.

ASSESSMENT & PLAN:

1. IgA deficiency: Common immunodeficiency with low likelihood of other associated immunodeficiencies in this case. Will order additional blood work to check other antibodies. Advised patient to watch for persistent infections or significant changes in abdominal symptoms. Instructed patient to inform healthcare providers of IgA deficiency if needing blood products in the future.

2. Type 2 Diabetes: Continue management with Metformin and lifestyle modifications, including moderation of diet due to family-owned donut shop.

Follow up as needed after additional lab work is completed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient is an adult who presents with right elbow pain for the past four days. The patient reports that the pain began after engaging in pottery activities during the pandemic. The pain is located on the inside of the right elbow and radiates slightly into the forearm. The patient denies any trauma or previous injury to the right elbow. The pain is rated as a 6/10 and has been affecting sleep and daily activities. The patient has tried ibuprofen with minimal relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Musculoskeletal: Endorses right elbow pain and discomfort in the forearm.
• Neurological: No numbness or tingling reported.
• Psychiatric: No depression or anxiety reported.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: Vitals are stable.
• Musculoskeletal: Positive for pain to palpation of the medial epicondyle of the right elbow. Positive for pain with pronation of the forearm. Positive for pain with resistance against flexion of the right wrist.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right elbow: No fracture or bony abnormality detected.

ASSESSMENT

The patient presents with right elbow pain consistent with medial epicondylitis, likely due to overuse and potential damage to the tendons that bend the wrist towards the palm.

PLAN

1. Rest: Order a sling for the patient to wear while awake.
2. Ice: Apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes, three times a day.
3. Medication: Ibuprofen 600 mg q.6 h. with food for one week.
4. Activity modification: Hold off on pottery work for the next couple of weeks.
5. Follow-up: Schedule a follow-up appointment in one week to assess progress.

The nurse will provide the patient with a sling and schedule a follow-up appointment.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain and shortness of breath.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

David is a patient who experienced chest pain and shortness of breath while walking outside. He fell and was taken to the emergency department. He reports ankle swelling and has a history of hypertension. He has been taking Bumex, Cozaar, and Norvasc inconsistently. He admits to not following a strict diet and consuming salty foods.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: Endorses chest pain and shortness of breath.
• Respiratory: Denies difficulty breathing at rest.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies abdominal pain, nausea, or vomiting.
• Genitourinary: Denies urinary urgency, pain, or incontinence.
• Musculoskeletal: Denies joint pain or swelling.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Vital Signs: Blood pressure 128/72, other vital signs within normal limits.
• Neck: No jugular venous distention.
• Cardiovascular: 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable from previous exam.
• Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• Extremities: Trace edema in lower extremities.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram: Preserved ejection fraction of 55%, normal diastolic filling, mild to moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive heart failure: Likely due to dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Bumex 2 mg once daily.
   • Specialist Referrals: Consult with a nutritionist for dietary advice.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Weigh daily, call if weight gain of 3 pounds in 2 days.

2. Hypertension: Continue Cozaar 100 mg daily and Norvasc 5 mg daily.
   • Additional Testing: Order renal artery ultrasound to rule out other causes.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Encourage consistent medication adherence and follow-up with nutritionist for dietary management.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Sharp pain in the right side of abdomen below ribs for several days.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a male patient who presents with sharp pain in the right side of his abdomen below his ribs for the last several days. The pain moves to his lower abdomen and into his groin. The pain comes and goes, and he has difficulty finding a comfortable position when it occurs. He reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine. He has taken Tylenol for the pain, but it has not provided relief. He feels nauseated but has not vomited. He has a family history of kidney stones and has had them before.

PAST HISTORY

Kidney stones.

FAMILY HISTORY

Father had kidney stones.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

Abdominal exam: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs.
CVA tenderness: Positive on the right flank.

RESULTS

CT scan of abdomen: 0.5 cm kidney stone located in the proximal right ureter. No evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT

Acute nephrolithiasis (kidney stone).

PLAN

1. Encourage increased fluid intake to facilitate urination and help pass the stone.
2. Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6-8 hours as needed for pain. Continue alternating with Tylenol.
3. Provide a strainer for the patient to strain urine and collect the stone for testing.
4. Order a basic metabolic panel, urinalysis, and urine culture.
5. Schedule a follow-up appointment in 1-2 weeks. If symptoms persist, discuss further treatment options such as lithotripsy or ureteroscopy.
6. Instruct the patient to contact the clinic if symptoms worsen.

INSTRUCTIONS

Increase fluid intake, take prescribed medications as needed, use the strainer to collect the stone, and follow up in 1-2 weeks or sooner if symptoms worsen.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Nonhealing foot ulcer on the right foot.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Nicholas is a patient with a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy, presenting with a nonhealing foot ulcer on his right foot. He first noticed the ulcer approximately six weeks ago after wearing a tight pair of shoes. The patient initially experienced a blister, which later became unroofed with thick, soft, mushy skin and yellow drainage. The patient's primary care physician started him on antibiotics six days ago. The patient has been experiencing fever, chills, and a foul smell from the wound. The wound has turned black around the outside, and the patient has been experiencing cramping in his calf muscle and a red streak along the inside portion of his calf muscle. The patient also reports difficulty catching his breath and coughing over the last two days.

The patient's blood sugars have been trending in the 300-400 range over the last two weeks, with one spike at 500-600. His A1c is 6.7, which has been stable for the past two years.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Integumentary: Endorses nonhealing foot ulcer with foul smell and yellow drainage.
• Respiratory: Endorses coughing and difficulty catching breath.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses cramping in calf muscle.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Vital Signs: Slight fever, otherwise stable.
• Foot Exam: Necrotic wound on the right heel, approximately 2x2 cm, with sloughing tissue, cellulitis, and erythemia. No bony exposure. No palpable dorsalis pedis or posterior tibial pulses, but present via Doppler.
• Vascular Exam: Bilateral palpable femoral and popliteal pulses.

Results:

Right foot x-ray: No evidence of osteomyelitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Nicholas is a patient with a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy, presenting with a nonhealing foot ulcer on his right foot.

Nonhealing diabetic foot ulcer.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy, with a nonhealing foot ulcer on his right foot.
• Additional Testing: Order a test to check blood supply for the wound.
• Medical Treatment: Debridement in the office today, culture, and potential change in antibiotic therapy based on culture results. Monitor redness and swelling in the calf.

Diabetes management.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has a history of diabetes with a stable A1c of 6.7, but recent blood sugars have been trending higher.
• Medical Treatment: Follow up with endocrinologist and continue monitoring blood sugars closely.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 7 days.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite on right knee.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient reports a tick bite on his right knee that occurred approximately one week ago. He is unsure of the exact location where he acquired the tick but spends time outdoors and went hunting a couple of weeks ago. The bite area is warm, painful, and has a bull's-eye rash. The patient denies fever, chills, joint pain, difficulty moving the knee, and problems walking. He has not been previously diagnosed with Lyme disease.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Hypertension
Diabetes

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Lisinopril 20 mg once daily
Metformin 1000 mg twice daily

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital Signs
Blood pressure: 122/70
Heart rate: 67
Temperature: 98.4°F

Heart
Regular rate and rhythm, no murmur, rub, or gallop.

Lungs
Clear to auscultation bilaterally.

Right Knee
Erythema, edema, and area of fluctuance over the right patella. Pain to palpation of the right anterior knee. Full range of motion of the right knee. Bull's-eye rash present.

ASSESSMENT

1. Tick bite with possible Lyme disease
2. Hypertension
3. Diabetes

PLAN

1. For the tick bite, start the patient on doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for three weeks. Order Lyme titer and Western blot to confirm Lyme disease diagnosis.
2. Continue Lisinopril 20 mg once daily for hypertension. Order lipid panel to assess cholesterol levels.
3. Continue Metformin 1000 mg twice daily for diabetes. Order hemoglobin A1C to assess long-term blood sugar control. Order basic metabolic panel to monitor kidney function.

The patient is in agreement with the plan. Instruct the patient to continue monitoring blood pressure and blood sugar levels at home. Schedule a follow-up appointment to review test results and assess the patient's response to treatment.
